channel.description: Recent content in Blogs on VRchina.cc

item.title: The Forbidden City
item.description: When a Chinese dynasty is overthrown, it is usually the tradition that the old palace must be razed to make way for a new one in its place. But in the summer of 1644 the Manchus broke with the age-old habit, sparing the already fire-damaged residence of their predecessors a similar fate.

item.title: Humble Administrator's Garden
item.description: The beautiful waterside City of Suzhou in Jiangsu Province is most famous for its elegant classical gardens. Among these, the Humble Administrator’s Garden is the largest and most renowned. It is considered as one of China’s four most famous gardens, together with the Beijing Summer Palace, Chengde Mountain Resort and Suzhou Lingering Garden.

item.title: The Terracotta Army
item.description: The Terracotta Army is considered one of the greatest archaeological sites in the world, and one of the greatest discoveries of the 20th century. It is significant because the hundreds of detailed life-size models represent the army that triumphed over all other Chinese armies in the Warring States Period, and who ushered in the united imperial China era 2,200 years ago.

item.title: Mount Tai
item.description: The leader of the “Five Sacred Mountains”, Mt. Tai is located in the center of Shandong Province, lying across the cities of Tai’an, Jinan, and Zibo. Its main peak, Jade Emperor Summit, which is within Tai’an City, is about 1,532.

item.title: Yungang Grottoes
item.description: Yungang Grottoes represent the excellent achievement of Buddhist sculptural art of ancient China, and it is the largest among the four most famous ancient grotto complexes in China. Yungang Grottoes with 252 caves and 51,000 Buddhist statues are the classical masterpieces of Chinese Buddhist art in the 5th and 6th centuries.

item.title: A Panoramic View of China
item.description: Since the introduction of economic reforms in 1978, China’s economy has been one of the world’s fastest-growing. As of 2016, China is the world’s second-largest economy by nominal GDP and the largest by purchasing power parity.

item.title: Along the River during the Qingming Festival
item.description: Along the River During the Qingming Festival is a panoramic painting generally attributed to the Song Dynasty artist Zhang Zeduan. It captures the daily life of people from the Song period in the capital, Bianjing, today’s Kaifeng in Henan.

item.title: An Admirable Woman Tu Youyou and Her Achievements
item.description: Tu Youyou, born on 30 December 1930, is one of the three winners of the 2015 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine. This winning event is a landmark success of herbal experts.

item.title: Beginning of the World
item.description: It may seem that every culture has its tale about the creation of the world and the beginning of mankind, so it is true of China. The beginning of the universe was nothing but chaos, and the heaven and the earth were intermingled - big black egg being commonly used as an analogy.

item.title: Characters of Chinese Cuisine
item.description: Chinese food culture is a precious part of Chinese culture. China is a vast country, taking up most of Asia and claiming much of its eastern coastline, which makes food in China vary from east to west, north to south.

item.title: China's Political System
item.description: The people’s congress system is China’s fundamental political system. The Constitution of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) provides that state power belongs to the people. The National People’s Congress (NPC) and local people’s congresses at all levels are organs representing the people in exercising state power.

item.title: Chinese Alcohol History and Culture
item.description: In China, alcohol is also called the “Water of History”, because the stories of alcohol can be traced back to almost every period in Chinese history. A legend says that Yi Di, the wife of the first Dynasty’s emperor Yu invented the method to make alcohol In ancient China, since alcohol was regarded as a sacred liquid, only when people made sacrificial offerings to the Heaven and the Earth or ancestors was it used.

item.title: Chinese Bronze Mirrors
item.description: It seems so natural for us to carefully dress up in front of a mirror every day. However, before the invention of glass, mirrors were made of copper. To be more exact, they were bronze mirrors.

item.title: Chinese Embroidery
item.description: The earliest examples of Chinese embroidery stem from the Zhou Dynasty. These might well represent the origin of embroidery, but early examples of which have also been discovered in ancient Egypt and northern Europe, though there was no conclusive proof of exactly where embroidery originated.

item.title: Chinese Ethnic Groups
item.description: China’s population is over the other countries in the world, and the efforts of different ethnic groups contribute a lot to her glorious and diverse historic achievements. As a large united multi-national state, China is composed of 56 ethnic groups.

item.title: Chinese Food Therapy
item.description: Chinese food therapy or nutrition therapy is an ancient practice in Traditional Chinese medicine that relies mainly on the consumption of natural food to heal the body. In Western countries, physicians generally regard dietary changes as an important part of medical treatment but not the primary cure to most diseases.

item.title: Chinese Jade Burial Suits
item.description: Just fifteen of the extraordinary head-to-toe jade suits that promised immortality to the Chinese imperial family have ever been found. The ancient Chinese believe that when a person dies, he or she will enter into the afterlife.

item.title: Chinese Paper-Cut
item.description: Paper-cut is a very distinctive visual art of Chinese handicrafts. It originated from the 6th century when women used to paste golden and silver foiled cuttings onto their hair at the temples, and men used them in sacred rituals.

item.title: Chinese Porcelain
item.description: Chinese ceramics show a continuous development since pre-dynastic times and are one of the most significant forms of Chinese art and ceramics globally. Porcelain is so identified with China that it is still called “china” in everyday English usage.

item.title: Chinese River Dolphin
item.description: The Chinese river dolphin is a freshwater dolphin and one of the most endangered animals on Earth. It is also known as the Yangtze River dolphin, baiji, white-flag dolphin, and white-fin dolphin.

item.title: Chinese Seals
item.description: Chinese seal engraving can be traced back to more than 3,000 years ago to the Shang Dynasty when the inscriptions on tortoise shells and bronze were available for recording happenings and ideas of human beings.

item.title: Chinese Shadow Puppetry
item.description: Shadow puppetry, also known as shadow play, is one of China’s historic folk arts. Performed by three to five puppeteers, shadow puppetry is a form of storytelling that uses puppets against an illuminated backdrop to create the illusion of movement.

item.title: Chinese Students Mobility Trends
item.description: With a population of almost 1.4 billion and a burgeoning middle class, China sends more students abroad than any other country in the world. Around 460,000 Chinese students were enrolled in foreign educational institutions in 2014, a rise of eleven percent over the previous year.

item.title: Chinese Traditional Operas
item.description: There are five main types of Chinese operas: Beijing, Henan, Yue, Huangmei and Cantonese Opera. Beijing Opera With almost two-hundred-year history, Beijing Opera is one of the most influential Han operas in China, and the quintessence of Chinese culture.

item.title: Chinese Zodiac Stories
item.description: There are many legends and mythology related to the Chinese zodiac and there are various versions of stories popular in different regions. Why were there twelve animals in the zodiac calendar and how did the scheme order come from?

item.title: Chinese Local Specialties
item.description: Local specialties in tourist cities of China have become a part of tourism. While enjoying sightseeing, visitors can also have a taste of all kinds of specialties in China. The following are some of the famous local specialties.

item.title: Classification of Chinese Poetry
item.description: The development of Chinese poetry can be divided into three main periods: the early period, characterized by folk songs in simple, repetitive forms; the classical period from the Han Dynasty to the fall of the Qing Dynasty, in which several different forms were developed; and the modem period of westernized free verse.

item.title: Crested Ibis
item.description: The crested ibis is a rare and precious species in the world. In history, crested ibises were widely distributed in East Asia. Since the middle of the 20th century, its population has reduced rapidly due to the change of the inadaptable environment caused by human activities, such as the decrease of the rice fields, the wide applications of fertilizers and pesticides and the reduction of forest area.

item.title: Dove Tree
item.description: The Dove Tree is a medium-sized deciduous tree, usually placed in the tupelo family, but is sometimes included in the dogwood family, and by yet others given the family status of its own, as Davidiaceae.

item.title: Drama and Great Fictional Novels in Yuan Dynasty
item.description: The Mongols were nomadic people who herded cattle in the north of the Tang Empire and wandered over a large area fighting on horseback. In China, the Mongols established the very rich Yuan Dynasty.

item.title: Education in Ancient China
item.description: A good education has always been highly valued in China. As far back as the Shang Dynasty, inscriptions on bones or tortoise shells were the simple records of teaching and learning.

item.title: Ginkgo
item.description: When we think about flowering plants, there are about 350,000 living species. And in an evolutionary sense, they’re equivalent to that one species of ginkgo. They’re all more closely related to each other than they are to anything else.

item.title: Golden Snub-nosed Monkey
item.description: The beautiful golden snub-nosed monkey has blackish-grey shoulders, upper arms, back, crown, and tail, with the back being covered in a longer layer of fine silver hairs. In males, the sides of the head, forehead, and neck and underparts are a bright golden color, hence the common name of this species.

item.title: Heshi Jade
item.description: From Neolithic times, the Chinese have been extremely fond of jade and have made this magical stone an inseparable part of Chinese culture and art. In China the national passion for jade gave that stone much the same superiority that lapis lazuli had in Sumer and the Chinese saying “Gold has a value; jade is invaluable.

item.title: Historical Background of Dream of the Red Chamber
item.description: This massive, sprawling novel of China was written in the mid-eighteenth century. Cao Xueqin, the author of “Dream of the Red Chamber”, was born and raised in an aristocratic family, but he died in misery and isolation.

item.title: Hundred Schools of Thought
item.description: The Hundred Schools of Thought is the name given to philosophers and schools that flourished from 770 to 221 BC, an era of great cultural and intellectual expansion in China. Even though this period, known in its earlier part as the Spring and Autumn Period and the Warring States period in its latter part, was characterized by chaos and bloody battles, it is also known as the golden age of Chinese philosophy because a variety of thoughts and ideas were freely developed and discussed.

item.title: Laozi and the Daodejing
item.description: Laozi was a philosopher of ancient China and was a central figure in Taoism, also spelled “Daoism”. Laozi means “Old Master” and is generally considered an honorific Laozi is revered as a god in religious forms of Taoism.

item.title: Life of Confucius
item.description: Confucius has the greatest influence on Chinese characters. Besides being a great educationist, thinker, and unsuccessful politician, he was, first of all, an intellect with a noble morality. He pursued truth, kindness, and perfection throughout his life and his success and failure were largely due to his character, which had an everlasting impact on Chinese intellects.

item.title: Looking Up into Space
item.description: Since 2011 China’s space industry has witnessed rapid progress manifested by markedly enhanced innovation and access to outer space, constant improvement in space infrastructure, smooth implementation of major projects such as manned spaceflight, lunar exploration, the Beidou Navigation System and high-resolution earth observation system, and substantial achievements in space science, technology, and applications.

item.title: One Dedicated Scientist and Agricultural Advancement
item.description: Yuan Longping was awarded 5-million-yuan State Supreme Science and Technology Prize for his high yield hybrid rice species in 2001 and 2013. This award is viewed as a “Chinese Nobel Prize”.

item.title: Origin of Chinese Characters
item.description: As one of the most ancient characters, Chinese characters have played a significant role in the development of Chinese culture. Originally, ancient Sumerian and ancient Egyptian symbols existed, but only Chinese characters remain today.

item.title: Spring Festival
item.description: The first day of the first lunar month is regarded as the New Year of the Chinese- the Spring Festival. It is the most important and ceremonious traditional festival in China, just like Christmas Day to the Westerners.

item.title: Standard Mandarin
item.description: Standard Mandarin, also known as Putonghua, which means “common speech”, is China’s official language. It is the language of education, government and law and almost all foreigners who study Chinese will learn this dialect.

item.title: Sunzi and The Art of War
item.description: Sunzi is the reputed author of “The Art of War”, which is considered the best single book ever written on the subject of war. Of Sunzi himself, little is known beyond his birth in the state of Qi and service to the emperor Helti of Wu.

item.title: The Belt and Road
item.description: Complex and profound changes are taking place in the world. When Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Central Asia and Southeast Asia in September and October of 2013, he raised the initiative of jointly building the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21 st_Century Maritime Silk Road, which have attracted close attention from all over the world.

item.title: The Book of Changes
item.description: “The Book of Changes”, or I Ching in Chinese, is unquestionably one of the most important works in the world. Its origin goes back to mythical antiquity, and it has occupied the attention of the most eminent scholars of China down to the present day.

item.title: The Chinese Dragon
item.description: The Chinese dragon, “Long” in Chinese, is a symbol of propitious omens and good fortune. The Chinese dragon has many faces, nine sons and multiple cosmic roles. It is everywhere- in the clouds and heavens, in the rivers, the oceans and in the underworld where it guards jewels and precious metals and creates volcanoes when it bursts out to report to heaven.

item.title: The Development of Civilization in China
item.description: China is an East Asian country with a large territory, a huge population, and an ancient history. With written records dating back 4,000 years, it is recognized as one of the four great ancient civilizations of the world, together with ancient Egypt, Babylon, and India.

item.title: The Dragon Boat Festival
item.description: Falling on the fifth day of the fifth month according to the Chinese lunar calendar, the Dragon Boat Festival is one of the greatest significant occasions among all the festivals widely celebrated in China.

item.title: The Ever Shining Four Great Inventions of Ancient China
item.description: China’s long history has seen some extremely important inventions emerge, most noticeably gunpowder, paper making, printing and the compass, which, in the words of Roger Bacon, changed the whole appearance and status of things in the world.

item.title: The First Chinese Library in Mexico to Promote Cultural Exchange
item.description: The first China-themed library in Mexico was inaugurated on Monday, April 24, 2017, in a bid to promote cultural exchange. Books on Chinese history, art, culture, traditional medicine and music, among other topics, as well as digital and video archives, can be found at the new Chinese Library at Mexico City’s Anahuac University.

item.title: The Five Key Flavors of Chinese Food
item.description: Over China’s vast territory, the flavors of cuisine vary from one region to another, and usually one or two of the five flavors dominate. Flavor preferences can reflect features of geography, climate, agriculture, culture, and history.

item.title: The Legend of Dong Yong and the Seventh Fairy
item.description: Once there lived a very poor family, with just a father and his son. One year a brutal drought destroyed the land, and sick with sorrow, the father passed away, leaving no inheritance for the son.

item.title: The Origin of the Double-Seventh Day
item.description: Legend has it that every year on the night of the Double-Seventh Day, the Weaving Girl in heaven and the Cowherd would meet at the Magpie Bridge. The Weaving Girl is a beautiful and smart fairy with deft hands and the women in the mortal world will beg for intelligence and deft needlework from her; hence July 7 of the lunar calendar is also called Begging-for-Dexterity FestivaL Therefore, the Double-Seventh Day is more than a Chinese Valentine’s Day.

item.title: The Silk Road Dream of China's High-speed Trains
item.description: Generally speaking, a rail network that offers 200-350 km/h trains is an HSR (High-Speed Railway) network in China. High-speed trains were once the preserve of Japan, with its “bullet train”, and France, with its TG~.

item.title: The Story of Nezha
item.description: According to the work Fengshen Bang, Nezha was born during the Shang Dynasty in a military fortress at Chentang Pass. His father was a military commander named Li Jing, who later became the “Pagoda-wielding Heavenly King”.

item.title: The Tomb Sweeping Day
item.description: The Tomb Sweeping Day also called “Qing Ming” in Chinese has been a traditional Chinese practice for over 2,500 years and falls on the 15th day of the Spring Equinox, which usually falls on the 4th or 5th of April.

item.title: Traditional Chinese Lantern Festival Held in the UK
item.description: Traditional Chinese Lantern Festival is an emerging project in the events of “Happy Chinese New Year” in the UK in recent years. Since 2014, it has been alive in the UK.

item.title: Water-Splashing Festival of the Dai People
item.description: Water-Splashing Festival is the most ceremonious traditional festival of the Dai minority group. It usually takes place in mid-April of the solar calendar, often ten days before or after the Tomb-sweeping Day, and lasts three to seven days.

item.title: Yangtze River and the Yellow River
item.description: Yangtze River Winding about 3,964 miles, the Yangtze River is the largest in China and the third-largest river in the world after the Nile in Africa and the Amazon in South America.
